title-group.article-title: Du Bellay's Changing Attitude toward Reading from the "Deffence & Illustration" to the "Regrets"

p.mixed-citation: This essay was presented in much briefer form in the 16th-Ccntury French section at the Northeast Modern Language Association meeting, March 22, 1978, in Albany, New York, under the title '"'Fueillete de main nocturne & journelle.. Du Bellay's Conception of Reading in the Deffence & Illustration. "
Joachim Du Bellay, Lu Deffence & Illustration de la Langue Fruncoyse, ed. Flenri Chamard (Paris: Marcel Didier, l%b), II, iv. 1(17.

"Pas plus dans la satire que dans l'élégie, la création poétique ne peut se réduire à la transcription fidèle d'une émotion, d'une impression ou d'une observation person- nelles. Du Bellay reste toujours un artiste, qui stylise l'impression pour la plier aux exigences d'une forme savante et complexe: le sonnet" (Henri Weber, La Création Poétique au XVIe Siècle en France [Paris: Nizet, 1955], I, 400).
"11 y a, dans les Regrets, un élément livresque, factice même" (Screech, Regrets, op. cit., p. 13).

Chamard speaks of this aspect of the Deffence when he says: "Négligeant l'orateur, dont a traité Dolet...il s'en tient au poète et va tracer de lui, non pas un portrait idéal inspiré de Platon, mais une ébauche plus réelle, procédant d'un souci d'institution pratique..." (Henri Chamard, Histoire de la Pléiade [Paris: Didier, 1961], I, 191). Dassonville also comments on what he finds to be excessive practicality in the Deffence: "Ce pragmatisme de la jeune Brigade est tellement cynique qu'on a peine à l'admettre" ("De l'unité de la 'Deffence et Illustration de la Langue Françoyse,"' BHR, 27 [1965], pp. 96-107, p. 104).
Michel Charles has also suggested this relationship, in his treatment of the stages of medieval and Renaissance conceptions of the reading process (p. 133).

Michel Dassonville speaks about the Platonic aspect of this transformation: "Le but de l'étude des Anciens est de s'assimiler à eux au point de retrouver le secret des relations qui unissent une œuvre d'art à son Idée" (art. cit., p. 105).
Robert Griffin, Coronation of the Poet: Joachim Du Bellay's Debt to the Trivium (Berkeley: Univ. of California Press, 1969), p. 31.

"Both poetry and oratory are considered, for purposes of the discussion, as subordinate to language: 'le poëte & l'orateur sont comme les deux piliers qui soutiennent l'edifice de chacune Langue'... this must mean that through their efforts as creators both poet and orator contribute the desired qualities to the language in which they write" (Bernard Weinberg, Critical Prefaces of the French Renaissance [Evanston, 111.: Northwestern Univ. Press, 1950), p. 20).
See Ong's discussion of the ambiguities involved in the audience of a diarist, in "The Writer's Audience is Always a Fiction," PMLA, 90, 1 (January 1975), 9-21.

"A literary work is not an object which stands by itself and which offers the same face to each reader in each period. It is not a monument which reveals its timeless essence in a monologue" (Hans Robert Jauss, "Literary History as a Challenge to Literary Theory," New Literary History, II, 1 lAutumn 1970J, p. 10).
